reviewText:
After two long hours of trying to outwit this gangly coward in a dense forest with everything from camera pigs to obscene language, I stumbled upon the ruins of its chalet up in a narrow mountain pass. There I found a sniper rifle, almost as if that's what it was planning to screw me over with next. I took that sniper rifle and, that night, baited the creature into a barren basin at the foot of a hill where I shot it half to death as it ran around screeching in pain and baffled rage. It eventually fled back to my camp where it murdered my pet pig out of spite before I blew its face open ten feet from the treeline it was attempting to ambush me from.
I had a wonderful time with Rake but you know, I wouldn't have done if I didn't have to suffer its outrageous failings first. If this was anything approaching a competent experience with well tuned mechanics, I'd have killed that yellow little freak in like ten minutes and forgot all about it. But I will remember this. I will remember the joy of plugging it full of lead from a hunting blind as it sprinted from one end of the hill to the other, wondering where its tactics had failed it. Sometimes to kill a monster, you have to play one.
Check out the hunt below.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=He3liV9r348

Getting bored.
Walk outside in the morning to see pig heads impaled on sticks and my trailer is covered in blood.
This gangly freak knows where I live.
I set up bear traps and reposition the cameras and go to bed. As soon as I wake up, that scrawny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ breaks my window and smacks me across the face.
I watched the cameras and wait for him to coem back.
He comes along and kills my pet pig because he knows I loved him.
One by one, he breaks all the cameras that are facing my camp, effectively blinding me.
I hear footsteps and he walks by my window.
Shot him in the ♥♥♥. He react by screeching and jumping through my window.
Rip. 10/10 would play again.

reviewText:
For three days and three nights, my world has been a slow-burning terror. I just wanted to kick back in the forest. Sunbathe on the warm rocks. Mingle with the gentle deer and playful pigs that roam the valleys. Until the monster came. Soon, I was being spied on every moment. I could no longer luxuriate nude in the green grasses. I could no longer ride the pigs for amusement. It arrived in the belly of a metal beast. It's glassy eyes spread throughout the woods. It raided and stole from the many places I had once frolicked. It lured and trapped my pig friends, only to bind more all-seeing eyes upon their delicate heads. At night, it would watch for me. Waiting so that it might make sport of hunting me.

The first night, I wanted only to fall into slumber outside its many invasive eyes. I destroyed them as they hung suspended from the trees. Perhaps if I could make it understand that I only wanted my peace and privacy, it would leave. But alas, my efforts were in vain. By the next night, all damage would be repaired. The eyes continue to watch.

I met my once-friend pig in the woods outside the monster's encampment. My dear friend had succumbed to the monster's evil. Its eyes stared dumbly back at me, even as that all-eye watched from atop a tortured head. I had no choice. I had to set my once-companion free. I whispered gently as I held his head in my arms, stroking the matted fur. I whispered of times now past. Of romps through the forest and friendship now gone. I twisted then, violently. His head came away in my arms. I wept bitterly, my tears salty in my throat. I left the body there. I could not bear the sight.

The second night, the nightmare was born anew. More dumb stares. More friends gone to the tortures of the thing hiding in the metal beast. I stared into the glass eyes of the metal beast, catching glimpses of the villain. My rage grew. I took the heads of my friends, determined to send a message. I would not back down any longer. It would not break my resolve. My friend's deaths would not be meaningless. I mounted them. I left them standing proudly upon pikes. Accusing eyes leveled at the hidden monster. To greet it when it emerged with the morning. To haunt it as I was now haunted.

The third night, I knew what had to be done. I could be passive no longer. I would confront the evil that besmirched my woods. I would cleanse it from the earth. It had set traps for me. Metal teeth digging deep into my vulnerable flesh. I screamed in pain. But I remembered my pig friends. I remembered their pain. Their sacrifice. I pressed on. I could see it inside. I leapt.

A resounding boom. A hot, heavy pressure hit my chest. My ribcage shattered with the force. I fell backwards. The metal beast was opening, but I could not see through the haze of my pain. I could only taste the copper in my mouth. Feel the burn spreading through my body as my life ebbed away.

The monster was standing over me. I looked up at it as the last of my life left me. I wanted to ask it. Why? Why did you torment me? What pain did I ever cause you? What pain did my beloved friends ever cause you? It looked down at me without pity.

There was another blast. The sound seemed to split my ear drums. Then nothing. Only the blackness.

10 / 10 - Would roleplay again.

reviewText: This game is truely amazing, with a masterpiece idea in mind. Obviously the game has a few weak spots, but dont all games? . When I first got it, my friend told me to stop being a wus, leave the RV and hunt the Rake. I was pretty scared but he said the monster was rediculous. I was walking through the woods when I heard footsteps. It was the rake. It wasnt too scary causeI heard him from a mile away and he wasnt very stealthy. Then I saw there was an update. After I saw the patch notes, I saw he had a new model and improved AI (along with a few other things). I had a good feeling about the update. It was night 1 and I decided to walk outside. I began aproaching the swamp, when out of NO WHERE he jumped me from behind and took away half my health. I knew this game was WORKED ON. It went from me just hunting the rake senselessly, without being scared what so ever, to me being forced to use a strategy. If I didnt, not only did I die, but I also blew a hole through my underwear. My point, dont judge a game of the first few days. It is an AMAZING concept and will continue to be worked on. IGN 9.5 outa 10. It has incredible potential and great features. This is definatly worth the 5 bucks. It IS scary, and I reccommend it to anyone who is a fan of this type of thing (Please keep in mind my review goes off my standards for a game by such a small and inexpirienced company. Konsordo did the best he could to the extent of his knowledge, and to create a game as great as this is good enough for me.)

Directions
1. Heat the oven to 400°F. Spray the bottom and sides of an 8-inch square pan or 9-inch round cake pan with the cooking spray.
2. In a 1-quart saucepan, heat the butter over low heat until melted.
3. In a large bowl, beat the melted butter, milk and egg with a fork or wire whisk until well mixed. Add the cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder and salt all at once; stir just until the flour is moistened (batter will be lumpy). Pour batter into the pan; use a rubber spatula to scrape batter from bowl. Spread batter evenly in pan and smooth top of batter.
4. Bake 20 to 25 minutes or until golden brown and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Serve warm.

reviewText:
Rake is a very unique horror game experience so to make this short here are some of the Pros and cons of the game.

NOTE: I am only putting down what I can remember from last time I played, which was about an hour ago so I can't pin point everything I had to say about this game.


PROS:
-Scary (Alot of people are saying that it isn't scary but in all honesty if you immerse your self in the game it can be pretty freaking scary.)
-Beautiful land to explore (even though the graphics aren't the best everything looks great, during the day everything pops and just looks amazing.)
- Not a slender clone ( The dev used a very well known creepypasta/myth to make a game that isn't about exploring in the dark and collecting papers for no reason.)
-Challenging (The game just throws you into the world with little to no knowledge of what to do or where to go)
- immersive (With this game having a very minimalistic hud its very easy to get caught up in what's going on)
I had more but these are the ones that I felt mattered


CONS:
So this game has alot going for it but I managed to find a few things that needed improvement.
-Nights last far too long from what I can tell they last about 30 minutes (unless I missed a way to move quicker)
-Very little instruction on what to do (I'm never actually sure if I should be exploring at night and not just hide in the trailer)
- The game is a tad too dark (I know its a horror game set in a forest but when you can't tell where you're going nothing can really get done unless you have your map out the entire time.)
- Buildings are hard to pin point on the map
- (This is a very minor complaint) The camera static can get really bad at times and make It very hard to see anything.
- Emptyness (there is alot to see but very little to gain from exploring, you can find some really cool stuff like a water fall,   a few abandoned buildings. ECT. but most the time there isn't anything there.)
- Framerate ( its seems to work okay but it doesn't like to run over 50 unless im looking directly at the ground.)

This game is amazing, its probably the best horror game to come out of the indie scene this year, its intense, scary, immersive, and just plain fun. I really hope the dev sees this and fixes some of the issues i've listed so that the game can become a much more entertaining experience. I would recommend this to people who are willing to put some time into a horror game and explore the world it give you. Its absolutely worth the $5.  7/10 (not perfect but good)

reviewText:
Gamers, take note: when a game has positive reviews, yet the vast majority of reviewers only have 30 mins to 3 hours in the game, there's a good chance something is very wrong, and Rake is not an exception. It's too bad as well, because a friend was kind enough to gift this game to me - I really wish I could recommend it. :(

Simply put, what we have here is a great concept poorly executed with terrible pacing and wonky controls, a game with flashes of brilliance that gets boring and tedious extremely fast, yet looks fun if heavily edited on Youtube. Some would even call it PewDiebait.

The game starts off promising: you're a ghost hunter" camping out in the woods looking for something  not entirely natural. You grab your cameras
recommended: and you set out to explore your surroundings and set up some surveillance. The atmosphere can actually be pretty good at times
hoursPlayed: and you'll probably experience a jump scare or two at some point
voteText: but then unfortunately
helpfulPercent: the game falls apart.\n\nThe cameras you set up? They occasionally provide you with a super-spooptacular glimpse of the creature
votesHelpful: but you realize pretty quickly that your only goal is to kill the monster - and cameras don't help with that. Instead
votesTotal: you step outside your RV
votesFunny: wander a few feet away
commentsCount: wait for the sound of footsteps
column16: turn
column17: and fire.\n\nAgain
column18: and again
column19: and again. If you do this enough you kill the creature and you win. If you don't do this enough
column20: you lose. You might think I'm exaggerating the simplicity of the game
column21: but I'm not. This is literally what the game boils down to
column22: once you see through the uselessness of cameras
column24: and exploring. Considering that's all this game has to offer
column25: considering its extremely short length and redundancy
column28: you're better off picking up something else for the $5 asking price."

reviewText:
Most games force you to run away from the scary monster, this game forces you to hunt it down and kill it. Rake is an interesting game based off a Creepy Pasta of the same name.

You play as a hunter in the middle of a forest with a hunting rifle and sniper rifle to defend yourself with. During the day you set up digital cameras, animal feed and bear traps and during the night time you sit in your caravan, watch your cameras for movement and try to find The Rake somewhere out there in the darkness.

It's terrifying at first until you realize The Rake reacts the same way every single time, running straight towards you, knocking you over then running away. Once you get a bead on his location it's easy to keep him in your sights and make sure he never gets the drop on you, even if it does take 30 odd shots to put him down.

This is a neat concept but deceptively basic and there isn't all that much to talk about or experience. Like the Slenderman games it seems to hinge more on the popularity it has as a Creepy Pasta, more than it does try to be its own thing. It's not early access but it sure does feel like it at times and Unity engine is at its unoptimized best, dipping into single digits on the lowest graphical settings.

I guess if you have a Let's Play channel this is a no brainer to pick up, everyone else might want to hold off.

Full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HeNbr8qLiyM

reviewText:
As a scientist/ hunter (he multiclassed, I guess) you are out in the wilderness trying to track and hunt the elusive creature known as the Rake: you'll do so using a decidedly skimpy equipment selection featuring a rifle, a few cameras, some bags of feed and a pair of binoculars.
Rake manages to turn a somewhat interesting creepypasta entry into a boring, clunky and insipid mess of a game where little enjoyment can be found.

PROS:

-there's at least a few places to explore and a smattering of loot to be found (bear traps, sniper rifle etc)

CONS:

-insipid graphics and weak sounds

-simplistic AI

-dull, clunky gameplay

-firearms feel weak and their ironsight view is badly zoomed out making aiming a chore

-unwieldy controls

-the ingame Rake is different from its creepypasta entry, it looks different and acts just like an intelligent animal

-a few niggling issues like rain happening indoors or the getting back up" animation playing even after the Rake killed you

reviewText:
Prepare for the longest review I will probably ever write. Mostly because I can, it's an enjoyable foray, but needs serious work.

[Warning; sailor talk and potential (minor) spoilers below]


(As of 10/20/2015,) I'm giving this project a very tentative yes and thumbs up. As has been said before, and I completely agree, this game has a lot of positive elements going for it right from the start.  For so little content, the idea is extremely fetching, and the replay value is surprisingly high, even WITH the ending being what it is (without bothering with detailed spoilers, beating the game in its' current state should result in a chuckle, smirk, or at least a raised eyebrow).

Observing the (fictional) cryptid in the dark of night with limited range night vision cameras and nothing but the otherwise-calming sounds of nature to comfort you, or a wide-angled, convenient set of.. well, a magnified monocular, which when paired with a flipped on flashlight, mystically becomes wide-reaching suitable night vision mode. *shrug* Having Rake scramble from the dark to knock the crap out of the cameras provides good tension and a startle or two.

Finding this critter's den, or traces of it's prey, be it hominid or otherwise, stumbling a little too close in the daylight only to get ♥♥♥♥♥-slapped to the ground by the thing before it takes off because you will quickly learn that it is an absolute virtuoso premier in dickery, is all good stuff, and offers immersion.

So I had some difficulty in figuring out precisely what the goal of the game was.  It is clear you were intended to be armed. It was also fairly clear that you are immediately encouraged to deal with your closest forest friends, (pigs), who like archangels at the wings of Saint Michael, ... are sent forth into the dark calamity of hostile woodlands, blind and dumb, but with cameras attached to their necks so you can sit in your camper and watch with intense interest as they wander aimlessly, keep getting caught in your trap (which has no feed in it), and occasionally saunter into the unlucky spot where the Wendigo is watching, who sprints by and slaps the life out of their poor, succulent, delicious bacony bodies. I am unsure what sordid pleasure the protagonist gains from this viewing, but I admit to partaking in it a few times. While you can catch a pig, there was no indication that you could catch Rake, and furthermore the magic journal which I will mention, makes no mention itself of 'capturing' Rake as a priority.

You are given a fair amount of gear, at least that I've found, to work with. Several traps, a scoped rifle with an awkward two-round built-in magazine, roughly forty shotgun shells for your starter 'rifle' [an over and under model], (Sort of a misnomer considering shotguns don't usually have rifling), and, ah of course, unlimited amount of piglet feed!  Lovely. Absolutely smashing.  The piglet feed and cameras will respawn after each day. But that is where the limitless supplies end. You're also given a kind of PDA/tablet, which functions as a map and indicator of where cameras are placed, and nothing else.

You are lent a magical journal beside the desk of your interior camper, which updates itself automatically day in and day out, as though it is tied directly to the plot and your actions have no bearing on it whatsoever. Not that it would help enormously, as it's written in utterly heart-warming broken English, just like the controls setup menu. Bear with us.

There are several hunting blinds scattered across the map, and to my knowledge they affect an invisibility cloak over your character such that you can throw lead at the Rake without fear of his dreaded, horrifying open-hand slap. (I learned this from reading it, not trying it out, as it seemed rather stupid to me to detach yourself from your camera read-out hub in the trailer to stand around for a half-hour in some stubby, four-cornered, windowless tower to wait for Rake to appear).

Going into Rake combat..

You see, it seems dickery is key to the Rake, in a certain sense. It is difficult to kill, not because it is just so frightening that it's presence is unbearable, nor because it is all that powerful, or excessively intelligent. It is a pain in the ♥♥♥ because it's means of committing to mortal puglism is by sprinting by just under mach one (that is 766 miles per hour for you dare devils out there), open-hand slapping you as hard as you can upside the head, and trotting merrily away (at a leisurely 75 miles-per-hour) joyous and content in the knowledge that, should he die soon, he (I assume it is male) shall be projected straight to the Valhalla of frat boy ♥♥♥♥-butts, where he will serenely paint the faces of his drunken passed out peers with phalluses for the rest of eternity.  'Rake' is indeed a master of the cheap shot to the temple.  He ensures that after you've just been smacked to the ground he is well on his sprint to a nearby tree, after which, with perfect night-vision, he will commence masturbatory celebration as he watches you hold your aching head and glare angrily into the dark. At least, this is the kind of place I imagine that lank freakshow that I just killed would like to call heaven.

What I mean to say is that this fella is a hit and run fighter. It would seem also that a fair name for the creature could also be Wendigo, considering its' speed on the ground.


To run down the usefulness of each bit of gear, I take issue with what you're given and it's functionality. Cameras are only useful insofar as they function to take note of where the Rake is. Cameras are not numbered either. You have to use that noggin of yours to recall where each camera was placed and in what order, maximum of five. After they're destroyed they are, obviously, useless and lost until the next respawn. Being that at least half of the game involves setting up cameras, the limited use of them is something of a bother. Not that I expect auto-turrets, but some kind of intelligent system that allows an affected camera to sound out a short alarm, or for your otherwise-useless tablet to be able to remotely connect to the cameras.. that would have been nice. Instead if you want eyes in the night you have five cameras to look through, but only from the confines of your trailer, or your own naked eyes with assistance of a psuedo-nightvision monocular, or a narrow sight on the scoped rifle. Not very promising, really. And considering this Wendigo is lightning-fast, you aren't intended to be able to easily hunt him with eyes and luck alone.

The 'rifle' is handy more because of the amount of initial ammunition you are granted for it then it's lethality.  At something like 40 rounds, you may have just enough to kill Rake if you make every single shot count. Otherwise, you can easily see yourself running dry while the gangly little hooligan still breathes.


You're given a 'sniper rifle', which while I understood the purpose of, could not really bring myself to use since I knew of no definite way to lure the Wendigo into a long narrow passage about 60-80 meters away from me in a straight path, which is really the only locale under which I would personally find this rifle useful. The forest is too dense and full of sight-blocking brush.  You can't move when aiming it, which is fair, but as of writing this review, aiming the thing is tough enough due to the amount of awkward sway the scope lends at the slightest movement. The central sight will overshoot the actual point of aim quite easily, so in a sense you have to aim it in short bursts and hold it there to check where the actual point of aim is.  Not a great mechanic.  The protagonist also holds the sight much too far from his eye, as though it's a reflex sight and not a magnified scope.  Oh well.   A big issue with this weapon is it's finite ammo and two-round capacity.  If I recall correctly, you can find about 18 rounds with this weapon.

reviewText:
First of all I really like the concept of the game, it's something original :)

You are some sort of ghost-hunter. During the day you have to set up cameras and explore the forest. You can set up to 5 cameras in the forest at different places.

At night you have to go to your trailer and check the cameras for all sort of monsters/paranormal things on your computer. Everytime something moves inside the view of a camera, the camera button flashes red. Sometimes the cameras get destroyed by... well whatever you are hunting.

You have to go out then and set up a new one.

The aim of the game is to hunt down different creatures. You get a rifle at the beginning of the game.

It can be really scary at night but sometimes it's a little bit boring. The nights are too long and sometimes there isn't anything to do but to wait.

I haven't played much yet, but I had fun playing it and I will play a lot more :)

I think you can gather new equipment as well (saw it in the trailer) so maybe I'll add some more information to this review after I played a little bit more :)

You can't do anything wrong by paying 5 bucks for a game which is quite fun for a couple of hours.

Yup, I recommend this game, low price, original gameplay, and quite scary :)

reviewText:
Fun game! Here are the pros and cons of this game.

Pros:
-Beautiful landscape.
-Creepy atmosphere at night.
-Suspenseful! Even when in your trailer YOU ARE NOT SAFE.
-Moving pig camera...nuff said.
-Rake can attack during the day (although it is unlikely).
-You need to find some of the gear that is necessary for your survival (bear traps, sniper rifle, extra ammo, etc)
-You get to hunt the monster instead of just running away and hiding.
-MULTIPLAYER COMING.
-Open world.
-Based on a kickass creepy pasta!

Cons:
-Only 3 nights. More would be fun.
-Once your windows are gone, they are gone. You should be able to repair them.
-More bear traps would be good.
-Only 5 cameras allowed.
-Kinda slow the first two nights unless you look for the Rake.
-Only two weapons with limited ammo. Sucks when you run out.
-FPS never goes above 60 unless looking straight up or straight down(heard of this happening to others as well).

All in all, the game is pretty good but has room for improvement. The developer has made a game that is scary and fun. I would give this game an 8/10. I look forward to upcoming updates!

reviewText:
This game's graphics are obviously not great. And it appears to be poorly translated from some other language. But overall, the atmosphere is truly terrifying. Here is the story of my first night in Rake:

I had spent the day setting up trail cams. I had four set up a good distance from each other to get fairly good coverage of the forest. I even had one attached to a pig that aimlessly wandered in and out of my camp. Then when night came around, I sat in my trailer and monitored my cameras. It was mostly uneventful: I would stair at the screen and switch cameras whenever I saw a motion sensor go off, but it was always just a deer or a pig that had triggered it. However, the whole time I had this unending sense of being watched and found myself constantly checking the windows of my trailer to see if anything had wandered into my camp. I would even occasionally hear footsteps as that pig wandered through my camp again. But then, I saw one of my motion sensors go off again and clicked over to that camera. When I saw that thing shambling off into the woods and making some unholy moaning noise, I immediately began to question my decision to play this at 11 o'clock at night.

The game is honestly pretty scary and has a sort of Five Nights at Freddy's meets Slender feel to it. Definitely worth trying if you get the chance!

reviewText:
At first I was impressed with Rake; the sound design is genuinely unnerving and the graphics are bright to give the player a sense of security that the player questions as he knows the monster will show up.

In the search for The Rake I grew paranoid and jumpy as the forest hummed with unknown noise, I always felt like something could pounce on me at any moment. During that time I wondered what The Rake looked like, I assumed that he was as competantly designed as the other aspects of the game.

But then I met The Rake.

After the first encounter I quickly realized how not scary Rake is and I was utterly dissapointed after the tremenous buildup. The Rake has an extremely predictable pattern, he runs up to you for 4 seconds and then attacks which takes a sliver of health from you (But you can heal yourself, so who cares). All you have to do is shoot him before he attacks you and you'll give him damage, shoot him enough times and you kill him. I won the game during the first night.

While I do not reccomend you buy Rake, I do reccomend you watch this developer for future games; as I said I was impressed by many aspects and I think the dev has shown allot of improvement from past titles.

reviewText: Game has been abandoned by the developer.  I think the concept is interesting, but the game only has basic functionality.  You have a gun, but it does so little damage that you might as well not have one.  The alien thing that you're supposed to be hunting/video taping/not being attacked by (I'm not even sure what exactly the goal of the game is) is pretty fast, and if he get's close enough to you, then you are automatically frozen, your camera is forced to turn towards him, he hits you and you fall down and then he gets away.  It seems futile because if you ever get close enough to see him he automatically attacks you without any time to react.  Just another game that was unfinished in Early Access, developer changed almost nothing, and then released it as a full game".  Just throw this game onto the pile that steam has been getting a reputation for lately."

reviewText:
IF YOU’RE SMART, MAYBE YOU’LL TURN THE TABLES ON THE MONSTER HUNTING YOU
This is one of those games that has a ton of potential, but a few problems. The nighttime encounters with the Rakes are fantastic, and produced more than one jump-out-of-your-seat scare while playing. That said, those encounters are few and far between, which means that much of the remaining time was a simulator on the boredom of setting up all the those traps and cameras that help provide those precious moments of tense gameplay. I’d say worth your time, given the price, especially if the frame-rate issues get fixed and multiplayer is introduced as promised by the developer.

Some actual gameplay footage can be found here:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=482398105
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=483148287
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=483891624

Pros
Music was appropriately atmospheric and creepy
Decent-sized map, allowing for a good bit of exploration
Excellent Rake AI – you never know where the creature is going to come fromCons
After a while the gameplay got somewhat repetitive
No tutorial and limited instructional mode
Terrible frame rate issues

reviewText:
Y'know, I was pleasently surprised when I started playing this. For $5 this isn't half bad and gave me more than one fright.

Its atmosphere is what did it to me, If you're into horror games and you also like creepypasta-esque monsters, you'll probably like this. It is only a Unity game so it doesnt look all that impressive but it is a really enjoyable game.

The idea of it is pretty cool too, as its about Monster Hunter kind of TV show person hunting down mythological creatures and I always did enjoy those shows as a guilty pleasure.

I suggest this game if you want a couple hours of cheap fun. One of the few actually half decent indie horror games as of late, can't wait to see more of where this game goes! Really hope I get to see some co-op to hunt down the Rake with friends, or for more monsters to join the fray. Mothman and Skinwalkers, please! And more maps.

reviewText:
So you want to know if  The Rake  is the game for you? Well, here is the check list that can  HELP  you!

IF YOU LIKE: Placing cameras

Dancing while holding cameras
Multiplayer - with cameras
Cameras that crash the game because camera!
Replacing cameras
Placing cameras with your headset off because this thing yells like there is no tomorrow

and endless respawn even though there is limited gun ammo making the game unbeatable because guess what:  even if you shoot the rake with every shot, he still has 3/4 hp :)

TL;DR  : 11/10 would rather divorce my wife than refund this.

reviewText:
(Author's Note: I put quite a bit of time and effort into this review. As such it's rather long. There's a TL;DR at the bottom for those of you who like to keep things short and sweet. Thanks for reading! :D )

I'm in a bit of a pickle here; while I cannot recommend this title in its current state, I also cannot condemn it entirely. It has the feel of being either a first attempt at game development, or at the very least the work of someone inexperienced. Thankfully, Mr. Google supplied me with confirmation of this suspicion. Of Konsordo's three titles on Steam, this is the only one with an overall positive rating. They're definitely not part of the human cancer that dumps sh!77y games on Steam and finds stupid ways to prevent people from getting refunds. They're just a small developer with limited experience.

I challenge anyone who reads this review to find any developer whose first few titles were flawless.

Unfortunately, Rake suffers from some flaws that are difficult to forgive. Poor optimization is one big glaring example. My rig isn't a monster, but it's decent. Despite that, I experienced frequent frame rate drops that rendered the game nearly unplayable. If it had top-notch graphics, I wouldn't mind so much. Sadly when I attempted playing this title on the highest graphics settings (clocking approximately 10 FPS), I saw that the game looked like something developed around 2008.

The controls are finicky. In order to place a camera, you have to position yourself just right, otherwise you'll be mashing the E key all day. Most of the items in your inventory are assigned a key to bring it out, but I found no way to put these items away once I had them short of opening the inventory and closing it again.

The AI for wildlife is a joke. When I set up a critter cam on a pig, every time without fail the pig would walk the exact same path, run into the exact same invisible walls, and then wander back into the live animal trap in the camp. Having to re-release the pig every five minutes got old real quick. It's like when they're not in panic mode, the animals are on invisible tracks, much like the NPCs in Morrowind, circa 2003.

The static effects on the game cams are overdone. This might sound like nit-picking, but it was bad enough to give me motion sickness. Over-effect is almost never a good design choice.

Another effect that seems to be overused is motion blur. No matter how slowly you move the mouse to look around, your vision blurs until you hold the mouse still. Even if you move the mouse just a few milimeters, you get motion blur. This can be incredibly disorienting. I understand that some people like the effect for immersion, but other games like The Forest give the player the option to disable motion blur if it suits them. If the developer for Rake had implemented this option, I would not have bothered mentioning this minor caveat.

That leads to my final issue with the title - the lack of Settings Options. The only chance you get to tweak anything other than sound and possibly brightness (I've forgotten what the second of the two options are and I've already started the Refund process as of this writing) is when you start the game; a window pops up with resolution, graphics settings and display options. That's it. Once you're in the game, you can only tweak sound effect volune and one other thing. This was incredibly aggravating on my first attempt playing, as I wanted to tweak the graphics settings to try and improve performance. Not being able to do so without rebooting the game was an annoyance that could have been easily avoided.

To give credit where it's due, the AI for the Rake itself isn't bad, and the jump-scares are pretty effective. It actually managed to get a squeal out of me the first couple of times I saw it. Unfortunately even interactions with this antagonist lack polish. While hunting the Rake, you only have a couple of seconds to react before it's in your face and taking a swipe at you. Once it's close enough to attack, the rifle straight up disappears from your hand and you're completely helpless. You can't run, you can't fight, all you do is stand there and let it smack yo' a$$. This might have been a design choice, meant to indicate the player character being frozen in fear, but if that was the intention there should be more indication of it than the rifle taking a trip to Narnia. Perhaps the character crying out, or at least whimpering and panting.

If this title were still in Early Access, I would definitely recommend it. Unfortunately, it's not, and as of this writing it still feels very unfinished. That being said, if I had the extra money to blow on a game that annoys me as much as it entertains, I wouldn't have asked for a refund. If you like to support Indie Devs, by all means pick up Rake. If you're like me and in the position where you only afford to buy games that you can get many hours of enjoyment out of, skip it and wait for future titles from Konsordo. I am confiident that given enough time and support, they will produce something great in the future.

TL;DR: Rake is a game with a great concept that lacks polish. If you can forgive amateurish mistakes for the sake of an interesting concept, give it a try. Otherwise, pass on it.

reviewText:
Bought the game.. Installed.. Everything looked fine.. Hardly saw any glitches or gamebreaking things.

Started playing. Put up some cameras. Noticed i placed them pretty bad.. Feelt sceptical about going out and changing them. Waited for night.. Excited as hell..

Dident see anything but pigs.. After 20 min inside my trailer watching the cameras i saw nothing but pigs and the occasional deer... Last 10 min I ran out with my gun shooting every thing i saw.. Still no creature.. Maybe It's meant so the creatue wont appere on the first day? Or maybe I was just Unlucky..

Still I got a feeling this can become a really good game.. With the Competetiv multiplayer where one play as the monster and other as hunter.. Also If they just keep putting in more stuff.. New areas to hunt in. New monsters to hunt and be hunted by. Perhaps more weapons or some kind of customisation to what you wish to bring on your hunt? And more equipment. Currently only seen cameras. Seen in the video that it do exist bear traps.


I give the game 6/10 Simply based on automosphere.. As they are doing a good job here.. The creatue from what i seen in other people videos.. Still need some work done. Specialy in it's animation.

I won't recommend anyone to buy the game yet.. Still I say give it a month then come back and see.. I sure as hell will.. Also will try out the second day.. See if i get some more action then.

pros:

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q9JM9gaou-c

If you want to see Rake at it's finest, my 6th part does that really well. If you didn't come here for shameless plugs of channels and their videos, then here is my honest review of the game.

I'm not one to turn away from games becuase of graphics, however this one had graphics that slightly did turn me away from this game. However, after looking at the reviews I did decide to buy it, hoping that I can look past them. I was not dissapointed. The game right off the bat had me scared, even in daytime. Then at night time, never have I felt so unsafe while walking around, never knowing when he is going to pop up. The atmosphere that this game creates in fantastic. Such a creepy atmomsphere that keeps you on edge. As the game progresses, Rake will start to get more and more agressive, and even start coming to your camp! It was then that I knew this game had done its job, I was scared at my own camp and even in my trailer..... I was scared no matter where I was. This game is fantastic for 5$. I didn't run into a single game breaking bug, in fact the only real bug I ran into was an invisible wall between two trees. That was the most noticable thing that was wrong with the game. Other than that no big problems for me, considering the price.

TLDR; Is it worth the price? Hell yes.

reviewText:
If you're here from Worth A Buy, it's worth the $5. I mean, what do you expect? Halo 5? No, you get what you pay for. It's fun and scary if you actually play the game and not sit in a corner just to kill the Rake. It's like playing Skyrim on PC and using noclip and god mode to win the game, it's very boring and brings no challenge.

Now, if you're just reading this because you want to know if you should buy it? I would say yes, I have gotten scared many times from this game, the Rake doesn't actually just jump scare you, but it will hit you from the side or behind if you're not catious, which will scare you.

I would definitely check this game out if you have an extra $5 to spend, and I will definitely play more hours on this game after this review. (currently have 2.1 hours)

reviewText:
2ND EDIT:

With new optimization, better Rake AI and finally some co-op multiplayer, the dev gets all of my praise for coming through and making their game worth the price of admision. It's still not perfect, it lacks polish and the concept could use some work, but it's creative, original and unique (yes, those all mean different things to me), and you'll be hard pressed to find horror games that are like that in the current market.

If you consider yourself a fan of horror, or are just someone looking to get a bit spooked and willing to overlook some flaws, you owe it to yourself to try this game out. For it's price, it's more than worth it.

-----------------------------------------

EDIT: The game's been updated since I wrote my original review, giving the Rake noticibly better AI and improving the game's overall performance a fair bit, which were two of my biggest issues with it at first. Multiplayer, however, is still nowhere in sight and is still announced as a feature in the game's steam page. Until this is added, I'm afraid I can't change the review to a recommend.

This game isn't early access. I bought it expecting a finished product, and although I'll give some credit to the creator for informing their audience that mutliplayer is still in the works (at the very end of the description), the fact is it seems like they're trying to blatantly misinform their costumers, which is never okay.

I'll edit this review as the game updates.

-----------------------------------------

reviewText:
Got this game in the last steam sales for about 2 euro which is a fair price for the content it offers. Its a hunt between you and the ´Rake´ which is a creature based on a creepypast story of the internet. By daylight you can prepare a bit (seach for beartraps, ammo, a second weapon, set up camera's etc) and by night you can watch throught your placed camera's (fixed, but there are multiple locations where you can put them) Or you can go outside and hunt for the Rake which is active and night seek you out (seems to have quite random behaviour) In the night i've never really felt safe.

This game is best played at night.

Its a good start for this developer and i hope he makes more games like this (only more fleshed out, in a couple of hours you've seen and experienced everything this game has to offer)

I looked out the window and saw the rake just looking at me, with dark eyes that could make even yo mama scream. Then i went out to confront him like a man but i didnt have more rounds of meh bb gun.\n\n10/10 would get scared by pigs again.

reviewText:
This game is probably one of the best horror games I have played.
A couple things I think would be cool if added into the game are...
1. More monsters. Although I'm not saying the game is bad with just one, It would be cool to see multiple monsters. That and it would help you not get bored by not seeing anything.
2. More cameras. I love the whole camera system, but I think you should be able to place more than 5.
3. Survival mode. I think it would be really cool to have a mode where you have to survive as long as you can with no breaks, and the longer you survive the more aggressive the rake gets. You would only have the one daytime to set up cameras and traps.
I think this game could be the next big horror game and was worth the $5
Short version of the above 10/10

reviewText:
One of the not so many games that does not rely on jump scares and instead it relies on atmosphere and wonderfully design AI. Some of the players say that the nights are too long, but that is the charm of the game. This is by far one of my most favourite horror games.
10/10 would be pushed from my trailer again.....

CONS:

- Can only place 5 cameras
- Takes 30 minutes at day and 30 minutes at night (It's a huge drag)
- During night time it's no where near scary, just boring
- Rake has the worst animation
- Bad gameplay
- The trailer is 100 times better than the game
- Complete rip off
- No multiplayer
- Stupid motion blur at night
- The animals scream and ♥♥♥♥ and it's really annoying



Would I Recommend This Game?

- No, I feel sad buying it...


Is it worth the money?

- No! 6 bucks to sit in a trailer and look at 'spooky' rake animations


Nothing Can Save This Game It's Sad.


Overall Rating?

- 0/10 Would Not Recommend

reviewText:
To start with a few negative points/those i think ought to be addressed:
- Bloom is way too high, please turn this down
- Some more weapons would be nice but that's more of a side point for sure, perhaps a revolver to add a faster firing but weaker weapon. Oooh and flares, can't have a horror game set innawoods without some flares
- The day/night cycle is pretty stale. Having the day visibly change to night would urge the player on far more

And that's honestly it. This game is truly what I believe creepypasta games should be, that building dread as you fall further into a story, becoming more invested in finding the truth, and then coming face to face with something horrifying. The rake, while not a very attractive world model, is to this game what the Blair Witch was to that movie, an almost intangible horror lurking JUST out of sight, far enough that you fear even hearing it but not so far that you don't want to stop. Adding dead camers was a masterful touch, it gives the player a choice of braving the unknown in search of the truth, or staying where it's safe and knowing nothing come morning.

And when you do decide to venture fourth, my god. The feeling is like those first few minutes of Fatal Frame that I haven't felt since I was twelve. I actually had to stand in the doorway of that trailer, truly apprehensive about going out there. It's like going down a dark halway in your house to see if that noise really was just the dog. You feel true dread, whether it's the sound design that is done VERY well for an indie game (blending the sounds of the Rake with those of the pigs is a key point) or the knowlege that the thing is out there, hunting you, every minute spent in the dark is heart pounding.

This game is doing for horror what many years of Triple A titles have fallen short and failed to do. It's made it about the story of the monster, the story of the man hunting the thing, and not about just some thing popping out of the dark with a scary face. More than anything, the devs UNDERSTAND that you do not have to see the horror to fear it, only knowing that it is there and it is coming for you. And it's doing all of this with graphics from 2005.

I absolutely CANNOT wait for multiplayer.

reviewText:
So here's my story:
I arrived in my van, and I collected all the crap in it and went outside.
After getting out I found a pig in my trap, I named him Jerry. Before I could put a cam on him he ran away (RIP feelings).
I went out on adventure and found a little road. I followed it and arrived at a green military shack thing, so I basically raided it and left the owner trapless.
I went back to check on my van and if my pig came back, and to check on my cameras, and some freakin' deer came out of nowhere and made a screech and ran past me (Almost giving me a heart attack). I watched in awe as he ran into the fields, never to be seen again. Until I found him and shot em' for making a scary sound.
I went back and found that the food I left by Jerry's cage was eaten, but no Jerry.
I went inside my van during night time after a long staring contest with a pig (he lost) and checked my cameras.
I saw the lil' Rake and ran after him with my shotgun, but no luck.
I came back to my van and he somehow got near my van and tore me to shreds.
10/10 would hunt for monster again IGN

reviewText:
My first impressions of this game.

NOTE: I don't revivew games often, this game was recommended to me by a friend and it was cheap so I thought I'd give it a go.

I ended up refunding it

This is the story of the first and last playthrough.

I began in a caravan, my immediate reaction was to look around and I found myself a rifle and some cameras.
I poked around the forest and set up cameras and managed to attach one to the pig,

So far so good!" I thought to myself as I returned to the caravan after setting up the maximum 5 cameras.
Upon returning to the caravan I discovered a 'skip day' option and clicked is thusly.

and this is where things get ♥♥♥♥

I spent the first 5 minutes watching my cameras
date: it was around this time where I got restless as nothing had happened except for a pig walking past camera 5 occaisonally. I spent another 10 minutes watching cameras and got stupidly bored.\nSo I decided to go outside and just look around. Then
hoursPlayed: I saw a figure dart across the horizon.\n\n"♥♥♥♥ing finally
voteText:
something has actually happened."

I fired 2 warning shots at the creature to which 1 must have hit it because a health bar appeared on the top of the screen.

A. ♥♥♥♥ing. Health. Bar.

The creature then ran up to me pinned down and struck me once and took a quarter of my health.
And when i say ran I mean awkwardly zig zagged up to me because the bushes/trees seemed to best its sub-par intelligence.

After it hit me

reviewText:
The fact that this game has overwhelmingly positive reviews is utterly baffling. The poor graphics and syntax-error laden text are excusable. Everything else that's wrong with the game: not so much.

The creators clearly have vision but lack the talent to see it to fruition. Either that or they're just really lazy. I'm not gonna lie; the concept is really cool but the execution is horroible. The game drops you off in a trailor in the middle of the wilderness without any direction or instruction. (You can find the controls in the setup menu before the game even launches and 3 brief pages of hints found in the main menu give you some vague tips of questionable merit.) Each day you get a new journal entry to read and even if you follow the direction to the letter it's no guarantee that you'll encounter the Rake. So far I can only see it in several locations that trigger scripted actions and give you no opportunity to shoot it (if that is indeed what the objective is) and hanging around camp on the final night. Even if you manage to get a few rounds off before it retreats into the woods, it takes dozens of hits for it to go down. Your ammo is limited so you need pretty high hit-to-miss ratio, which is harder than it sounds because you have no reticle and can't even look down the sights of the gun (the rifle has a scope but you only get 8 shots with that so good luck).

Now let's talk about the cameras: they're worthless. The journal entries stress the importance of setting up cameras to capture footage of the Rake (Is that the objective? Do I even have have to kill it? I really wish the game would let me know) but that doesn't seem to do anything. On the first night, it always takes out two of my cameras. I can see him do it but apparantly getting the video footage isn't actually important after all. You have a map that gives you the locations of all of your cameras, but they're not labeled so good luck figuring out which of the ten or so red marks is the one that the Rake was just at. Oh, yeah, and they all staticy and flicker constantly. I'm sure it's meant to be spooky but all it does is give you a headache.

I bought this game because it promised monsters. Technically it delivered that, but it is far from scary. It's good for a chuckle if you're playing with other people or just showing friends how terrible it is but as a serious game it is among the worst I've ever played. I just hope these can get some better talent in future spooky-monster games because it has potential. This game, however, realizes none of it.

reviewText:
I love the idea, the concept and the atmosphere of the game, and for the price it’s actually really good.

I cannot however recommend it due to very sloppy aim mechanics and clear need for development for a game that’s advertised as finished. The game does have some jumpscares however they can be very predictable. I am also unhappy that the game is not advertised as early access or in development as the multiplayer feature that’s advertised is still not released, despite the multiplayer option in the main menu. 3/10.

reviewText:
You know at first this game just tussled my interest nipples, like a man's tip gently caressing against the inner thigh. And then it ♥♥♥♥ed me, dry, day one, no holds barred, just bare back against the pavement like a cheap Thai hooker on the 4th of July. Until this game was optimized it resembled a half finished painting done by Picasso with his ♥♥♥♥, but after the recent updates, it started looking like a game, something I could engage in some daily foreplay with. The Rake however still resembles Smeagol either in heat or seeing each camera as the Ring to rule them all and is engaging in violent coitus.

Deep in the jungles I went, thinking it was going to be a thriller much like Predator but turned into a steaming pile of Favela's Great Big Hunt meets the Thornberry's as I was finding myself pouring wild feed into a cage to capture myself a wild Boar, strapping a camera onto it, and at night releasing it to the wild. It was like a Paris Hilton sextape; Skinny, somewhat attractive looking species looking into the camera in nightvision, with a sweaty, greasy hog like man creature being taken advantage of. It was then at that moment I witnessed first hand account of Rake ♥♥♥♥♥♥, Raking if you must.

2 cameras down, I sprawled up from my Trailer Bat Cave, climbed out and onto my roof in search of the dreaded creature that took my piggies life. Quoting Arnold here  You Ugly Mother ♥♥♥♥er" I shot twice in the direction of its asscheeks
recommended: that I a man and his rifle had caught and or killed the infamous Rake... but I was mistaken. I shot instead Bambi's mother.\n\nThis game is terrifying as it is heart breaking. This is more than a myth

reviewText: It's an a-okay game.  The $5 price tag is mostly justified.  Although the game optimization is pretty crap.  Getting 40 frames on average with a brand new GTX 980 Ti is not what you would expect from a game like this at 1440p on high settings.  The game content is quite limited at the moment with no purpose other than grab your rifle, set cameras up around the woods, and search for the mythical Rake.  If you want to buy a cheap game that will keep you entertained for a few hours, then go ahead and buy this game, it'll certainly do that.  But for me, it probably wont be a game that I come back to very often.  Overall it was pretty entertaining thus far and it definitely has an original concept that I found quite intriguing.  I'd give it a 6.5/10, give or take, pretty good.

reviewText: One of the very few creepypasta based games out there. Though this game was released literally two days ago, it is a fairly good game. Not really a lot of bugs. The pig's ai is actually really bad, but The Rake's ai is extremely intelligent. This game also has a tremendous scare factor. This is a good game if, like me, you love creepypastas and enjoy the horror genre. Buy at your own risk.

reviewText:
Really great concept! Picked it up today and enjoed playing throug the first game. The camera system is great , if a little bit janky when your watching the footage. The feeling of being exposed and hunted is great and the gun feels unweildly as it would do in the hands of some guy who isnt a trained soldier. Some more variety, new maps or monsters would be good.
Some points I picked up on:
1- The monster is very fast but does very little damage so it doesnt 'feel' like a threat once it gets you.
2- The first pig kept going into the trap ( not sure if intentional)
3- The monster can be predicable
4- The constant flickering of the cameras is unwatchable after a while, the flicker is fine once ever so often but its all the time.

Can I request you put some Lore or story into the game, even just fluff text on the board or diarys in the woods, and as I said new areas would be great! I think a haunted house level would be awesome!
Would it be possible for lets say a point system or something as a 'goal' to aim for, to gather evidence on the monster? or something......

Anyway I just want to say well done and this is a great game, you are obviously very talented game dev's and I look forward to more content in the future!

reviewText: This is a GREAT idea but it's execution stuttered a bit since the options menu is terrible with only mouse sensitivity and volume and no rebindable keys in the menu insted you have to do it in the launcher,the rake isn't too deafly since he does very little damage to you insted of instantly killing you like he would have done,and i would have like a difficulty slider since on the first day the rake knocked out two cameras and did absolutly nothing all night which saddedned me when i would have liked a mode where he was very aggresive and knocked out cameras very swiftly and hunted you down to your trailer on the first night.if this happenes on the 2nd or third night i don't know yet since i only beat day 1 so far.From what i heard this is planned on being a series with more creatures and if the dev does it should be a update or a big bundle that is at a cheap price and have a mission select for each creature and select which days to do as long as you beat the previous day. I also am looking forward to MP but im scared whoever plays the rake will just camp on the trailer,wait till the other player comes out and then smap attack them till they die.As a MASSIVE creepypasta fan i immediatly bought this game and do i thnk it's worth it? if he iron's out alot of the issues and can add more content to it such as the creature update or have the first game you buy be $5 and the rest be as dlc for the price of $1 and be added in the menu,then YES the athmosphere is spot on and i almost jumped out of my chair once which horror games rarely make me do,also one last thing iron sights for the rifle or shotgun would be nice to it can help alot of us aim. Overall if you have some spare money,want a good scare and are fans of creepypasta's buy it since you will probaly nit get dissapointed unless your like me where the worst thing so far is the framerate which he is going to patch.

reviewText:
I spent five dollars on the game, for the idea. I love the idea of hunting the monster with some simple gadgets. I can already see the graphics aren't the best and the gameplay mechanics are very simplistic. Those aren't the problem. The game is only five dollars anyway.

THE BIG PROBLEM.

The AI is literally too easy. The pigs and deers were harder to kill and hit than the actual Rake. The Rake will jog towards you and you can hear it a mile away. Just aim and shoot and it scatters off in the distance for a few seconds. Then it comes jogging back. Repeat, and repeat and it dies. So... Hopefully they can fix the AI or improve it, or something. Otherwise I can't recommend it. It didn't even jump in the trees or anything. That is my biggest problem with the game. The AI is a bore. If they patch it or improve it within this game, I will certaintly recommend this game.

As of now, it's a no. <-- OLD

EDIT*

The developers are working on this, I guess. There's no major co-op mode yet, or multiplayer. I can say that the game is much better if you play it like this: Night 1 don't go hunting, Day 2 go sight seeing, Night 3 fight!

I had a lot of fun editing this video that I made, this game is only five dollars (Still 2 dollars more than what I think it should be worth) and has some interesting ideas. The AI has improved a little bit, but would still like to see a lot of changes since this game does have quite a bit of potential. Would I recommend this? Sure, if you like making YouTube videos.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M-49aTvmToc

reviewText: This game has a concept that is too good for its implementation to do it justice. The concept of walking around at night, setting up cameras to try to get a glimpse of an illusive cryptid is an incredibly compelling premise. The execution, however, leaves a lot to be desired. Playing this game gives you a strong sense of the potential it has, and at the same time makes you understand how much potential has been unrealized. It simply isn't polished enough to be considered a good game, and the implementation of multiplayer is a buggy mess that usually guarantees a player will desync from the game entirely, making it unplayable. I could only recommend this game for what it could be someday in the future, but I have no faith that the developer intends to smooth the rough edges this game has. I would love to be proven wrong, but until that happens I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText:
{edit} Its been months and no update nor multiplayer. (26/10/15)

I'm going to go out on a limb, and recommend Rake its by a baw-hair mind you. Why you may ask? Even if you should understand that its gameplay can be like marmite you'll ether find it a fresh take on low-brow horror or a broken mess that has a interesting concept that hasn't really been pulled off. Waiting for action is more unnerving than seeing him. Two play styles to take note off; wait for him or try and find him. I suggest staying in the camper van like a big girls blouse, I think its safe there?

The lore about the Rake would be best researched online if you want a back story? To me, the games like trying to catch the neighbourhood vandal that dumps on your front lawn, where as you take part in a sort of a over the top hightech neighourhood watch scheme with a shotgun to catch the dirty naked bum or a neighour dispute thats run on for years and is very bitter would be another way of looking at it. There are two things in this world he (the Rake) hates more than you; one is the poor quality jumpy cameras and number two is pigs, in fact later he uses them to decorate your camper van and in general express itself with like a true artisan.

On a purely techical point, I've had no issues. I've yet to use my old all-in-one but on the gaming PC with a GTX 970, i7 4790k 4GHZ, 16GB RAM its not broke a sweat at all with max settings. Looking at the sceenshots it shouldn't be taxing anyway! its not ARK nor Metro:lastlight. [edit] Getting back to the old ideacentre i3 3GHZ, AMD HD 6400, 4GB RAM. I can play it at 720, windowed, low settings for around 20fps I'll let you wonder if that is acceptable? Afterall a i3 with a AMD 6400 GPU isn't for anything other than light gaming.

Its not all strawberries and cream, mutiplayer will only be LAN. Also can't comment on lan mutiplayer anyway as it will be coming in the next update. The online heros of the Devs are using excuses of using other software to by pass Lan only for online play. I can't think of the last time I've bothered/needed to do so, nor any developer that thinks its desirable nowadays. The more you play the AI has large flaws and gets to a point where you can easy cheat the game by blocking doorways with traps. Also they are already working on Rake 2 :S Shameless if you ask me. Konsordo also don't have a stella rep even if they seem to have got a winner in the eyes of a few here. For its price thou £3.99, its a interesting take on monster hunting it should offer a good few hours of gameplay IF you can bypass flaws that outside a indie -B movie horror game just wouldn't fly.

reviewText: The Rake is aclassic survival shooter without having to have any of the survival aspect such as food, water, and stamina come into play. The game is fun dont get me wrong, i love the concept but to be honest it is a steal for a game you will probably play for a whole day and some. But for others i would have to say the asking price is likely to go up in the case of an addition with multiplayer. in the end i can give this game a 7/10 while being a little boring at times but a full 8/10 if the multiplayer is going to be anything like i imagine.

now for the real review xd
well the game itself has pretty nifty ideas, yet needs alot of work to be a game your grandchildren would play
pros
- cameras
- night time atmosphere
- really good job about the sounds
- rake getting V8 rocket sistem after being shot at
- erotic screams it makes while running

cons:
- needs a lot more work
- weapon system is a bit, well, xd

All in all worth the money I spent on it, would recommend it. Get some friends and play it together, hotseat mode, hilarity guaranteed.

reviewText: This game has a concept that is too good for its implementation to do it justice. The concept of walking around at night, setting up cameras to try to get a glimpse of an illusive cryptid is an incredibly compelling premise. The execution, however, leaves a lot to be desired. Playing this game gives you a strong sense of the potential it has, and at the same time makes you understand how much potential has been unrealized. It simply isn't polished enough to be considered a good game, and the implementation of multiplayer is a buggy mess that usually guarantees a player will desync from the game entirely, making it unplayable. I could only recommend this game for what it could be someday in the future, but I have no faith that the developer intends to smooth the rough edges this game has. I would love to be proven wrong, but until that happens I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText: Tremendous waste of money.  I've seen other FPS games made with Unity that had much better graphics and ran much smoother.  The lack of direction makes the entire exercise kind of nonsensical guesswork.  Night time brought this bizarre kind of blurring effect every time the camera moved...  It was extremely distracting and made the entire thing very painful.  And when I finally did find the creature, repeated direct hits with the shotgun failed to inflict more than the most meagre damage.  Seriously, the hunting game at the local arcade is better and more realistic than this.  I totally regret buying this piece of crap.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. I expected it to be a scary, good executed game like Slender, since they're both based on Creepypastas. Sadly, this game came nowhere near good.
Correct me if I'm wrong, but each day takes an hour. A real hour. In real life. If you want to go through a whole day, good luck. You can sleep during the day, but not during the night, as you need to hunt down Rake.
During the day, you set up cameras and traps. At night, you look at those cameras, with gameplay stolen straight form Five Night's at Freddy's. I'm not a fan of FNAF, and even if you are a fan of it, this game is still boring. You sit there for thrity minutes, doing absoltely nothing, but staring at nothing. At least in FNAF, there were other things you had to keep track of, and the animatronics were a constant threat.
Of course, if you choose to go outside to find Rake, things get a little more interesting. The dark amospher and creepy sound effects are well done. You will get scared at the sound of footsteps, thinking it's Rake, but it's a boar. It's fun and creepy. Until you actually see Rake. Since the graphics aren't the greatest, he doesn't look all that intimidating. And he follows the same attack pattern every time. You can easily take him down if you figure it out.
The nights would actually be okay if you could do something else. This game should've had more survival gameplay. You don't need to get food, or drink water, or pretty much do anything. All you have is a health bar. At night, all you can do is stare at cameras for a boring time, walk outside for a little fun, or walk around your claustrophobic mobile home. You can't cook any food to eat, drink water, or anything fun.
2/10 Slenderman is better, and it's free. If this game was free, it might've gone up to a 3/10

reviewText:
i like this game a lot, for the price you cant go wrong. the gameplay is separate in days/night cycle you set up camera and explore during the day and try to kill the monster at night.

during the days beside setting up your camera exploration reward you with useful item. was time progress day 2, ,3, etc new event have taken place that keep the game interresting. you discover thing that where not there the day before. this greatly help making the days worth going through instead of just skipping it. one thing i did preciated a lot was the fact that the creature is STILL THERE during the day its just not active. can you find it?

the night is where the action begin you try to locate the creature with you camera and you rush to the area when you have locate it. the best part is that the behavior of the greature evole over time! making him harder was time progres. also when you find a easy way to track it something happen the next days that force you to change your strategy (dont want to spoil anything where)

there a few thing i dint like;

your camera can only set up a predetermine place.

the monitor on witch you watch you cameras flicker so much it have given me a headache i try to look at it the less possible.

if graphic is the most important thing for you when you purchase a game then look elsewhere. the animation are ok at best.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

This game is a very, VERY poorly unoptimized and unfinished game. I know it's early access, but this is ridiculous.
The game itself is unplayable, does NOT include the multiplayer like stated, and is not even scary.

Another thing about the multiplayer: The developer has stated in a review that the multiplayer will only be working over LAN. Okay, that's fine. But the thing about this which pisses me off is the fact that ON THE STORE page it does not state local multiplayer (LAN), just plain multiplayer. That's a very misleading selling point.

Please, if you are going to buy a $5 game, do not buy this one, since it is terrible.
I'm glad I didn't buy this and it ws gifted to me buy a friend instead.

reviewText: This game isn't scary at all. It's all jump scares. Except usually the jump is preceded by fast moving footsteps so you know it's coming. The game becomes completely boring when you realize that you're not trapped in the game with the monster: the monster is trapped in the game with you. The hunter becomes the hunted. And it's extremely easy to hunt the monster down and kill it within the first 10 minutes on the first night. It's not even a challenge.\n\nBesides all of that the game also suffers from bad translations and bugs and strange behavior from the monster such as walking straight up mountains that you cannot climb.

reviewerDisplayName: D E N T A L H Y G I E N E
reviewText:
Ok, from all my 2 hours of gameplay, I can make a short and simple review.

This game is the type of game I've been waiting for many years, just the concept made me instantly buy this. I'v always been a huge fan of supernatural things and cryptids so I knew I had to try this. And boy, I don't regret that one bit. The camera system is really well made, the creature can be terrifying and the nights make your heart race. This game has A LOT of potential, (not that it isn't good already) but as this gets updated more and more I believe this game will eventually shine.

When I started playing, I wasn't too impressed by the enviorment and the sounds, but when nighttime came, all that changed. I became so immersed and and frightened that I wasn't able to leave the truck at all. And when I finally did, the Rake is god damn terrifying. It's so dark at nights, and the Rake is so fast and unpredictable that those 2 things combined make the nights all out horror at least for me.

All and all this game is definitely worth the 4€. Would recommend for anyone who likes good horror.

reviewText:
Game has AWESOME atmosphere.  Despite the brightness being too high (and hardly any game options so you can't fix it easily), daytime being extremely saturated, and nothing happening most of the time... It still manages to be terrifying.  At least at first.  Most horror games rely on jump scares and constant danger (Outlast) but this game takes a completely different approach.  Now it's just you watching nighttime cameras and not knowing what, if anything, will happen.  The tension this creates is incredible... At least until you start getting bored.
In the end there isn't really much content yet and even when you do see the creature you'll probably be disappointed.  It's not the worst creature in a game but it doesn't match the sheer tension that has built up by the time you see it.  Disappointing really.  Once you learn how the game works and how the enemy behaves, the game becomes incredibly simple.

Overall I see a ton of potential here.  Enhance the enemy AI a bit, make it better animated (and get better textures if you can), and find something for the player to do during the long hours of the night when they eventually get bored.  As of right now it's fun for about an hour then gets stale, but it's also very early access and, in my opinion, worth every cent they're asking for it.  If you enjoy slow paced open-world type horror games, give this a shot.

NOTE:  Below is my story, it's long.  You've been warned.

Day One: It's bright out... Really bright.  Like bad hangover bright.  Other than that the place looks nice enough.  Plenty of gear lying around in the trailer I arrived in so I collect as much as I can and decide to head out and explore.  Five steps outside the trailer and a pig from hell comes darting out of the bushes squealing, probably laughing at my now soiled pants.  Oh well.  Onward!  After placing five cameras near my base I realize there really isn't much to do and if the HUD is correct I still have 25 real life minutes of daylight.  I explore a little bit but am excited to get to the meat of the game so I head back to the trailer and sleep until night.

Night One:  It's dark out and I'm already nervous.  Turn on the camera feed to take a look at what is going on only to realize that Camera 5 is already out somehow.  Did it go out in the day and I just didn't notice?  Or is something already out there?  I spend a full minute trying to work up the courage before finally blasting out my front door with shotgun in hand and running to where the camera was.  Surprisingly it wasn't as dark as I had thought, I could see well enough without the crappy little flashlight I had, but that didn't make me feel much better.  Upon arriving I saw that the camera was indeed gone but didn't hear or see anything else.  No sign of what had taken the camera out in the first place.  After standing there surveying the area for a few seconds I quickly replaced the camera then booked it back to the trailer, slamming the door as quickly as I could.  No idea why I got spooked, but I could feel a chill running down my spine from my little excursion.  Not a bad start.
I finally get back to the camera feed and began switching through the cameras.  Camera 1 kept sensing motion and blinking at me thanks to a pig that kept getting caught in a trap near my camper but everything else was quiet.  Saw a few pigs on the cameras but nothing else.
Ten minutes later I begin to get bored so pull out my phone to watch a Youtube video but make sure to keep an eye on the camera sensors in case anything happens.  Nothing.  Ten minutes left at night and nothing happened.  Starting to feel less tense and with the video over, I start switching through the cameras to try and learn the layout of the land better before I explore tomorrow.
Four minutes later I switch over to Camera 5 again and hear footsteps just out of viewing range.  Probably a pig again, but I decided to wait until it came into view.... About five seconds later the footsteps turn into running and my heart skips a beat.  Moments later the camera goes offline as some ungodly scream fills the audio.
I don't know if it was stupidity or courage but I decided to go out and find this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ while I still could, now that I knew where it was.  After sitting around for 24 minutes I needed SOMETHING to do.
Equipping my shotgun I begin sprinting through the woods, too scared to look around me for fear that the damn thing will jump out at any second.  Upon arriving at the site of Camera 5 I don't see anything but I do hear footsteps further up the path.  I quickly replace the camera then slowly proceed up the path, trying to see what is making the noise.  About halfway up the path I hear the footsteps turn into running.  Running in my direction.  I quickly bring up the shotgun and aim in the direction it's coming from, unsure what to expect...
And then I see it, a horribly animated and textured creature rapidly waddles out of the bushes before I blast it point blank range in the face.  A second later it's running off already, scared off apparently.  Fight or flight kicks in and I decide that fight is the best option, so I follow it.  Turns out the Rake is one of the loudest walking creatures on Earth (actually most creatures in the game are) so it's easy to follow.
I keep a clear area between me and it so I won't get caught by surprise in the underbrush, but otherwise am able to follow it easily.  After about tens seconds of chasing I hear it stop and return to normal walking speed, seems it finally calmed down.  I slow myself as well and carefully approach, trying to keep to open areas as much as possible.  Sure enough, I start hearing it run for me again and so I do what I did before, I wait.  Soon as it appears I fire again and off it runs.  Now it's become a game, with only a few minutes left.  I begin chasing it all over the map, firing as soon as it gets close then chasing after it.  No longer is this a horror game, now it's a funny game of tag.
Unfortunately the time runs out and instead of the sun coming up I get teleported back to my trailer.  Almost had the bugger too...  I had been hit once that night as he ran by me in a panic but my health was still pretty high so I considered the night an overall success.  Now to hope that he wouldn't heal during the daytime.

Day Two:  Exploring.  That's mostly what I did.  I found a few dead pigs (some with their heads on spikes) and a lot of old buildings and hunting stands.  Stumbled across one building where the Rake was apparently hiding out and got hit again as he took off out the door.  Scared the ♥♥♥♥ out of me but I was more disappointed that I hadn't gotten a shot off than anything else.  Health still looked good, about 80%.  Nothing to worry about.  More exploring yielded an area where FPS dropped down into the single digits, some ammo, traps, and a sniper rifle.  Not a bad haul.

Night Two: Now the game begins again.  I'm watching the monitors just to see where he comes from this time, hopefully it doesn't take all night.  About five minutes in I'm watching Camera 4, one that has a great view of a large open clearing near a lake.  I must have great timing, because I hear footsteps and a second later I spot him approaching the camera.  I wait until he breaks into a run to attack the camera before I exit the feed and take off after him.  No need to replace the camera now, this ends tonight.  After a ten minute game of tag I finally land the final shot on him with my trusty shotgun and am rewarded with You win!" on the top of my screen.  I should feel victorious
date: but honestly I feel a bit dirty.  The Rake wasn't really much of a threat after all
recommended: and learning his pattern so easily made the game a breeze.  Perhaps future updates will change this.  Perhaps he will become a true threat some day.  One can only hope."
