reviewText:
The Rake is an amazing horror game which include terrifying events that will leave you terrifyed for the nights to come.
For an early access horror game, I have to say the gameplay is fun but the graphics are simplistic (which I don't really mind). The grammer in the game could also be worked on a bit more because I spotted a few grammer errors in the journal and also interacting with things such as placing cameras on trees when you hit the limit of cameras placed. The ambient sounds are amazing in-game and can sometimes warn you that something might happen if you continue on the path you're following. I also liked the shaky cameras when viewing them because it makes it more horrifying looking at the cameras and watching the rake take it down. Although it felt really ironic because at the end, (SPOILER ALERT) you were actually trying to hunt and kill the rake before the rake killed you.
I'd have to rate the game an 8/10 because it is one of the most scariest games I've ever played. for an early access game, it's pretty fun exploring the map and discovering new places (keep in mind, the rake can show up during day time). I'm also really hyped for multiplayer because it will allow one player to play as the rake and mess around with the hunters (which can be pretty fun). I do hope that they implement random world generations in the future updates so that players will have a new experience every time they start off fresh.
Overall, the game is worth $5.49 and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys hunting and horror games.

reviewText:
I'm really mixed about this. Day one and two was absolutely awesome. It was horrifying and really well made. Day three however was a huge disappointment. The next part describes why.

It started fairly predicaple. My cameras went out fast and my pet pig had died. That was all fine and dandy until the actualy rake shows up. Then the situation transforms itself into a boss battle" with him. To get him out of the forest you need to get out and set up cameras. After that you go to your computer and look at the camera. When the rake runs up to the camera you run out with your rifle and shoot him. Now repeat that 20 to 30 times or so. It gets boring really fast. Sure the first time it is a little horrifying as he can smash your window and use some sort of orb to transport pigs with but that only happens the first time. The rest is just the process over and over. I killed myself with a trap because it was so boring.

That is my biggest problem with the game. Day one and two is well worth it's price. Day three not so much."

reviewText:
You play the role of a cryptid/fortean event hunter that is attempting to trap/kill his mother-in-law in a forest - 10/10 would kill a relative again : ]

Ok, so that was a jokey review that doesn't say much for this game.  Well, the true part is that your character is on a quest to discover the truth behind anomalous events/creatures - do these events exist/are these creatures real?, etc.

You have a number of motion activated trap cameras at your disposal that you can place on trees and even wild pigs (giggles like a little girl) that will aid you in finding your mother-i....er......the 'creature' once night falls.  You can also set feed and bear traps to aid you as well.  Thankfully you can skip the day segments and get right to the good stuff.  Now for the real problem with this game: the creature, or Gibbering Alien Man-Child (GAM-C) as I like to refer to it, takes 5,000 shotty rounds and/or bear trap encounters to kill it.  Ok, so it doesn't take quite that much damage.....but it is truly absurd just how much damage it actually does take.  I mean seriously, a couple well-placed shots to the head with your shotgun (yeah, I said shotty earlier though they call it a rifle in the game - it clearly is a shotgun, though there is apparently a rifle at some point, at least in multiplayer maybe...don't know, haven't played this game too much) should do the trick bu apparently the developers wanted to make this thing more difficult than Patriarch in Killing Floor on HoE difficulty.

Regardless, it's a pretty fun game and using the cameras and waiting breathlessly for the GAM-C to appear can be quite fun.  Just don't expect too much going in with only a $5 price-tag.

reviewText:
Okay, so. This game is still receiving updates even though it isn't Early Access any longer. As far as a full game goes, it's not the best experience in the world, but I would pay $5 for it. Fortunately for me, I got it on sale day before yesterday for $2.49.

I spent a few short hours in this game before I had been given the peak experience of the game. You play as a scientist in the mountain forests. There's wild boars and deer wandering around the map to add some life to the world. Although, they don't do much. The boars may wander into a trap at your camp which will allow you to place a camera on their heads to track their movements while they wander around the woods.

You can place up to 5 cameras in the woods, equipped with moton sensors to track the movements of both wildlife and The Rake within view. This is nice, but watching cameras can be almost unbearably annoying at times due to the amount of flickering" the cameras do. It's like an older VCR effect where the screen has some horizontal splicing. If it happened less often
date: I would be much happier with the camera system.\n\nThe Rake was creepy enough for the first few hours and he has a tendency of sneaking up on me
recommended: which provided some mild jumpscares. However
hoursPlayed: what I've seen of his AI turned out to seem a little bland. The Rake seems to wander the woods idly until he spots a reason to come after you or run away. I was able to find a deer stand overlooking an open swamp. It was there
voteText: I waited for two nights with my shotgun and sniper rifle. The Rake would wander aimlessly into the open where I would shoot him and he would either run away or sprint towrds me until I shot him a second time. Every time I did this
helpfulPercent: within two minutes
votesHelpful: he would come back for more.\n\nDeer Stands are a nifty feature
votesTotal: providing the player "Invisibility" to The Rake's eyesight. However
votesFunny: I'm not sure how The Rake interacts with players while they are within the safety of a deer stand. I don't know if I'm ever going to see The Rake while I'm in a deer stand because I don't know if he walks in my direction while I'm standing in one. Making it almost frustrating to stand in one and wait for him.\n\nYou have the ability to pick up animal feed and traps in the world. You can access them in your inventory and place them on the ground for an added "hunting" effect. However
commentsCount: these features seem rather unpolished
column16: ad boars will completely ignore the feed and I've yet to see The Rake go after any of my animal feed piles. Once I get The Rake to walk over one of my traps
column17: I will deem my experience with Rake complete.\n\nShould you pay $5 for this game? I'd say it's up to you. Different people may receive different experiences with the game depending on how they play
column18: so the game could not be worth the $5
column19: while others will find it worth more than $5. I would say

column26:

===Cons===

Could there be more? Yes, are the things in the game scary and enjoyable; yes. i even think what you get is worth what you pay. theres a few things that could improve but solid game 9/10 would change my pants just to be doused in pig blood, again.

reviewText:
I'm really mixed about this. Day one and two was absolutely awesome. It was horrifying and really well made. Day three however was a huge disappointment. The next part describes why.

It started fairly predicaple. My cameras went out fast and my pet pig had died. That was all fine and dandy until the actualy rake shows up. Then the situation transforms itself into a boss battle" with him. To get him out of the forest you need to get out and set up cameras. After that you go to your computer and look at the camera. When the rake runs up to the camera you run out with your rifle and shoot him. Now repeat that 20 to 30 times or so. It gets boring really fast. Sure the first time it is a little horrifying as he can smash your window and use some sort of orb to transport pigs with but that only happens the first time. The rest is just the process over and over. I killed myself with a trap because it was so boring.

That is my biggest problem with the game. Day one and two is well worth it's price. Day three not so much."

reviewText: Despite lower graphics quality and optimization, the game still is able to create a nice atmosphere and create tension pretty easily. The game may run out of things to do and become repetitive, but with a multiplayer upate on the way, and great atmosphere, it has lots of potential and is worth the current price in my opinion. The rake itself may not be scary after several encounters, and learning his AI patterns is very easy, but when he catches you off guard or you don't know his location, that's when the game shines. I say give it a shot and see what it has to offer in the future, and I think the content is worth the price, but in its current state, I wouldn't say it's worth more than $10, but still offers a good enough experience to be worth it.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential, I just shot a Lets Play for it and came to this conclusion. I played 2 nights because the day and night cycle actually lasts a long time if you are productive during the daylight hours. Unfortunately, the first day/ night was more of a tutorial since the game doesent have one built in. A feature I rather enjoyed was the fact that Ctrl and Alt are actually  aim and fire buttons as well which is cool if you're left handed. I am not, I just thought it was nice of Devs to put in. Day 2 I got the chance to explore and that was nice, I used up almost all my alotted time. I saw information and posts on a second weapon and traps. I was unsuccessful in finding either. The Rake is not terribly scary himself. His presence, at first makes you do a double take and he makes this noise that takes you off guard when he charges you but thats about it. The mechanic that makes you turn to face him while he attacks you should be changed, being forced to look at him takes away from the scary aspect. If the Rake is charging you from behind, he should just knock you on your face. In my Lets Play I also mention that I would prefer a shotgun over a rifle. Upon reading some stuff, I have found out that the rifle is supposed to be a shotgun but its Europian so it made sense to the devs. I mentioned that it fires like a Blunderbuss, there is only one bullet that comes out, there is no spray and upon actually inflicting damage towards him, each bullet is a sliver at a time. I do like that fact that through the night and going out first thing in the morning, you will notice the Rake will actually harrass you by breaking your stuff, killing pigs and leaving them beside the trailer and even putting pig heads on stakes. Again this game has a lot of potential and I look forward to doing another Let's Play on it when it has had some work done.

From now until the end,
DeathgripPlays

reviewText:
Oh my goodness. Let me first say that I have been dreaming of a game like this.

It's not just set on switching between cameras or collecting pieces of paper out in the woods, but it's a game that takes multiple elements from those other common horror titles.


The game starts you off in a parked rv, within the middle of a woodland clearing, giving you the necessary items to start your night's hunting. Yes, hunting is actually a part of this game. No longer do you have to be 100% victim to the elements or creatures that surround you constantly. In fact, you get a firearm as well as other protective items. These other items can be placed conveniently to hurt your enemies as well as to lure them to intended locations.


One of the coolest features of this game is that you can set up a minimum of five cameras around the map. The available placement spots for these cameras are pre-determined, highlighted areas on the sides of specific trees.
A black & white night filter is the only way you can visually see the environment through these cams. This is not a problem though seeing as how the filter does not seem to make trouble identifying things whether day or night. The availability to turn your cameras left or right in limited space is a neat little thing that Rake also offers.

Despite being made in the Unity engine, most affiliated with poorly made indie games, it is actually fairly decent in functionality and its playing mechanics.

The scares are great ranging anywhere from seeing these deadly creatures appear through security screens to the dreadful sound of fast running feet followed by immediate attack. I cannot describe how bad my heart attacks were from witnessing these things first hand.

Sounds make this game. The night sounds exactly how it would in the actual woods, the security feed buzzes and woops are oddly addictive to listen to, the animal sounds are loud and jolt inducing at times, and the little music that unexpectedly plays is reminiscent; in a good way; to Slender: The Arrival.


Now that I've listed all of the things that I love about this game, I will carry on to state the few issues I've had with it.


The monsters that attack you are, more often than not, way too fast to react to. If you were running around in the woods and you hear the quick moving feet of your impending doom, you're most likely not going to know where it's coming from let alone land a shot before you are stuck in a scripted taking damage scene. Please find a way to fix this. Maybe something like a faded bar of light that emanates from whatever side the monster is coming from could help. This along with the attack timing. Just give the player at least a few more seconds to respond. This is all to suggest that you are keeping this hit and run formula. If you plan on replacing the current attack script with a more advanced/realistic trigger event, then that would be even better.

Another thing on the monsters is the models. I'm pretty sure everyone has noticed that the implied different monsters of  the night have literally the same exact same model but reskinned. At the very least they have different sound effects, but the cloning of the monster designs just takes some of the fun out of the mystery and wonder of what they could've looked like. I hope that intentions are to change the models out for better and uniquely scary representations of what they're supposed to be. Please correct me if I'm wrong on the whole model thing.

An obvious would be the graphics. Yes I know that graphics don't make a game seeing as how I'm rating this game positively, but it would do this game such an amazing service. This game is already, for a majority, rated very positive. This is a good thing for a game based off of an internet story abused over and over for the use of rushed COLLECT ME!" games. If you can get a positive following for a game that doesn't even have impressive graphics
date:
then think of what will happen with the same game touched up with detail! This would also improve on the already great atmosphere!
Also I would find it hard to imagine you defending the graphics here.
I would not take you seriously if you complemented the hills/mountains in this game.

I have not found many bugs playing Rake
recommended: but I'm sure you can all agree that you've witnessed the "I can hear the cameras turn while I move side to side" bug. It's pretty funny to be honest
hoursPlayed: but it does not do anything to improve gameplay let alone atmosphere. To find it

Last thing to mention here is the menu screen. Don't get me wrong. I actually find the menu screen cool with the whole window blind moving side to side and equipment lying around everywhere thing. What I don't like is the buttons. I don't know why

It reminds me of how DayZ loads with it making you wait and then having you be in the world already yet with text still in your face. It just makes the processing feel awkwardly slow. Maybe it is though. All I'm saying is that it would be good to have the button displays clearer and somehow make the loading times feel quick and responsive. I know just asking for it doesn't make it happen immediately

reviewText:
The Rake is an amazing horror game which include terrifying events that will leave you terrifyed for the nights to come.
For an early access horror game, I have to say the gameplay is fun but the graphics are simplistic (which I don't really mind). The grammer in the game could also be worked on a bit more because I spotted a few grammer errors in the journal and also interacting with things such as placing cameras on trees when you hit the limit of cameras placed. The ambient sounds are amazing in-game and can sometimes warn you that something might happen if you continue on the path you're following. I also liked the shaky cameras when viewing them because it makes it more horrifying looking at the cameras and watching the rake take it down. Although it felt really ironic because at the end, (SPOILER ALERT) you were actually trying to hunt and kill the rake before the rake killed you.
I'd have to rate the game an 8/10 because it is one of the most scariest games I've ever played. for an early access game, it's pretty fun exploring the map and discovering new places (keep in mind, the rake can show up during day time). I'm also really hyped for multiplayer because it will allow one player to play as the rake and mess around with the hunters (which can be pretty fun). I do hope that they implement random world generations in the future updates so that players will have a new experience every time they start off fresh.
Overall, the game is worth $5.49 and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys hunting and horror games.

reviewText:
I played this game, it was one of the scariest horror games I have played in a LONG time. The graphics are lovely, it's realistic. And I screamed. Here is what happened...
Spoilers, if you don't want to know what happens, don't read this.
Morning 1 - I take in my surroundings, explore the place and put in some cameras.
Night 1 - Not much happens, I check my cameras throughout the night, not daring to go out.
Morning 2 - I see a corpse of a pig near the cage, thinking it was my pig. I check the cameras, finding out it was a different one.
Night 2 - I see a new corpse of a pig nearer my trailer. Still not my pig.. Still no sign of the creature
Morning 3 - I walk out my trailer, to find pig heads impaled on spears all across my camp. I feel terrified now, and I check my cameras, my pig is still alive. But one of my cameras are out, so I place a new one.
Night 3 - (It goes DOWN) I check my cameras (still too much of a wuss to go outside) still there are pig heads, but when I turn to my trailer, I see a gruesome sight, human and pig limbs are stuck all over my trailer. I become extremely worried. Then.. my cameras begin going out one by one, and then my pig is killed. I only have 2 cameras left, one far off and one right outside my trailer, I pray that it'll go for the one far off. I look through the one outside my trailer (Cam 1) And I see it... running past into the bushes, I scream. Then, the worst thing happens... Camera 1 goes out.. and im stuck with one last camera... the one far away. I can't bring myself to push E and come out of the cameras, but I finally do it. I look around my trailer then the unspeakable happens, he breaks right through my window, I scream the loudest I've ever screamed in years. But when I find im not dead, I feel better, I then see he only takes a small amount of health off me. I stay in my trailer, still too much of a wuss to go out. Then I see him outside the broken window, I shoot at him, screaming. He runs off, never to be seen again... Then I lose.
I recommend this game, it was an amazing and terrifying experience.

reviewText: While the graphics in the demo video are stunning, the actual graphics are not. The game is very buggy and has alot less to it than it appears. While it seems that there are 3 monsters to search for, there is only one. To be blunt, a very low quality monster.  The camera mod in the game is very plain and the monster is only out for a short time and does not have a good scare tactic. It 'jumpscares' the player one-to-three times per night, considering the night takes ~20 minutes, the scares become nonentertaining after the first two. In conclusion, save your money. Buy an Ice-cream cone or something, just not this.

reviewText:
Self multiplying bear traps in multiplayer 10/10

AJ Win!!!

In all seriousness, this was a fun game.  Single player made me almost **** myself and playing it with a friend was both creepy and hilarious.

At the time of this veriew Steam says I've only played two hours of the game, but that's because the multiplayer module launches seperately and doesnt let you use steam in-game (so no steam controller/big picture usability, unfortunately).  I've played probably a combined total of 10 hours with my friend at the time of this review.

One main issue I had is that the Rake is way too hard to shoot.  I haven't tried killing it in Single player, but in Multiplayer it took forever.  My friend and I did actually kill it in multiplayer and had some good laughs doing it, so it wasn't all that bad.  I think the bear traps should actually trap it instead of just damaging it as it runs over the trap.

I also wish the Rake was, I dunno, more dynamic.  The way it attacks feels so repetative that you never really get a chance to shoot it properly, and with that happening over and over again it made me think will this ever end?"

Also
recommended: I wanted to go over and examine my trophy.  But only mere seconds after the screen displayed "AJ WIN!!!"
hoursPlayed: my friend and I were booted out of multiplayer.  How disappointing!  I wanted to take a close up look at the thing I tried so hard to hunt.  Oh well.\n\nDespite its flaws
voteText: overall it's an enjoyable experience
helpfulPercent: I'd say worth the $6 I paid for copies for my friend and I on the Winter sale.  I'd reccommend it if you have any interest in cryptids/games about cryptids."

reviewerDisplayName: D E N T A L H Y G I E N E
reviewText:
Ok, from all my 2 hours of gameplay, I can make a short and simple review.

This game is the type of game I've been waiting for many years, just the concept made me instantly buy this. I'v always been a huge fan of supernatural things and cryptids so I knew I had to try this. And boy, I don't regret that one bit. The camera system is really well made, the creature can be terrifying and the nights make your heart race. This game has A LOT of potential, (not that it isn't good already) but as this gets updated more and more I believe this game will eventually shine.

When I started playing, I wasn't too impressed by the enviorment and the sounds, but when nighttime came, all that changed. I became so immersed and and frightened that I wasn't able to leave the truck at all. And when I finally did, the Rake is god damn terrifying. It's so dark at nights, and the Rake is so fast and unpredictable that those 2 things combined make the nights all out horror at least for me.

All and all this game is definitely worth the 4€. Would recommend for anyone who likes good horror.

reviewText: Rake is a survival hunting horror game. And it's terrifying as ♥♥♥♥. I thought wandering around a forest was supposed to be peaceful, like Minecraft, but oh no. If you thought Slender or The Forest was the scariest time you can have in the woods, you were all wrong. In the day it's fun to hunt deer and pigs, and place some cameras. You say to your self, This can't be that bad! I have a rifle!" Then night strikes and you're thrown into an endless darkness of terror. The eyes of the Rake and the other animals that inhabit these woods all look the same

reviewText:
Camera 5 just went offline and I didn't even see it happen. The monster works fast. Fast enough that a few moments later my pig-mounted camera shuts off as well. This time I switch over just in time to watch it lunge. By now I have a pretty good idea of where The Rake is roaming tonight, so I grab my gun and prepare to hunt the beast down...

TL;DR at bottom

There are many out there who feel that the found footage" genre of film popularized by Paranormal Activity and Marble Hornets is played out and tired. I do not count myself as one of those people. One thing that
recommended: is pretty incredible about Rake is that I kind of feel like the guy holding the camera in a found footage film.\n\nLet me start out by saying you're not randomly trapped somewhere collecting pages for reasons unknown. This is a horror game where you have set out to find the creature in question
hoursPlayed: and you didn't come empty handed. The bread and butter of the game is the ability to set up cameras which you can watch from your base camp. They rotate at your command
voteText: and can be put in a number of different places
helpfulPercent: and even attached to the back of a live pig. The restriction on the system is that you can only place five cameras at a time
votesHelpful: and they aren't invincible. The Rake will go out of his way to destroy hundreds if not thousands of dollars worth of your equipment. ♥♥♥♥♥♥.\n\nYou also have a gun. This is a monster that can be killed if you're smart and fast enough. It's not easy
votesTotal: but it's possible.\n\nThere's a pattern that I quickly fell into as I played. During the day I set up cameras and traps galore
votesFunny: and when night falls  I monitor the cameras and wait for the beasty to show himself. As soon as he does
commentsCount: I take my trusty shotgun and begin the hunt for the creature. Oftentimes
column16: it feels more like the creature is hunting me. I haven't reached an end state yet
column17: but the gameplay is unique enough where I want to keep trying to best my supernatural foe.\n\nA walking simulator this game is not
column18: which is a relief since most creepypasta based games function in that way. Story takes a back seat here
column19: which is fine since it allows you to make your own stories.\n\nThere are some drawbacks I feel inclined to mention. The camera system feels like a missed opportunity. It's not terrible
column20: but you're limited to a select number of trees and angles. I would love to see in the future an update that allows me to mount a camera just about anywhere
column21: as it would make the gameplay far more dynamic. The graphics of the monster are mediocre up close
column22: as it kind of looks like you're being attacked by an even smaller and skinnier Gollum. When it's fully dark and he's sprinting through the brush towards you he's pretty scary
column23: but in the off-chance you encounter him during the day you're likely to shake your head a bit.\n\nCurrently there's only one map with static elements. Either a couple more maps or a procedural generation element to it would be extremely welcome. The game is rather inexpensive
column24: and you get what you paid for
column25: but it's just exciting to think what this game has the potential to be.\n\nI'd like to note that I'm rather impressed with Rake's AI for both the monster and the wildlife. I've been scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at night by a boar more than once
column26: and The Rake is pretty good about making sure you only catch fleeting glimpses of him. He's animated pretty well too
column27: which helps sell the experience more.\n\nTL;DR: I've been so tired of the corridor walking simulators that pass as horror games these days. This is the first game in a while I've played that throws wrinkles in the formula
column28: and that in its own right is commendable. For 5 dollars
column29: you'll get a pretty fun game that might warrant more than one playthrough
column30: if only for the memorable mechanics! If you're a horror fan

reviewText:
The game is an amazing concept. It really is. It combines a lot of aspects of the surivavl horror genre together. Elements from FNAF and Slender are used to creat something that is truly terrifying.... the first time you play it.

True... the Rake scared the crap out of me the first time I tried to play through. I almost ♥♥♥♥ when it came running up on me out of the bushes. But as time drew on, I really became less and less phased with the generic and drab jumpscares. You can't really predict where it's gonna be, but eventually you'll find yourself wading through bushes just to shoot at it. Not to mention the camera system is pretty much useless for the most part. Only 2 cameras on the entire map are actually useful, and they're in the most obvious locations (right next to the camper), the others are there for the lol's. The pig camera, if you can't guess, is the most useless of the lot. Last but not least, the Rake is like taking the fear factor of someone like Mike Tyson, and giving him the punching force of Miley Cyrus. He doesn't do enough damage to be even remotely scary.

How could the devs remedy this?
-More damage from the Rake.
-More diverse/interactive nights.
-More/freeplace camera locations.
-Differnt selections of maps.
-Multiple Rakes.
-Different creatures.

All in all, it's not a BAD game. It's good for one or two playthroughs where your adrenaline is elevated. After that it's only good to scare your friends when they might come by for a visit. Would I pay 5$ again? Probably not. Do I regret buying the game? No. 5/10

It's a good game."

reviewText:
Set up cameras around my camp on the first day.
Waited all through the night and didn't see a thing.
Went out and got the sniper and the bear traps on day two.
Put camera on pig. Name him Pete.
Set pig loose in the night.
Rake breaks on of my cameras then goes silent.
Getting bored.
Walk outside in the morning to see pig heads impaled on sticks and my trailer is covered in blood.
This gangly freak knows where I live.
I set up bear traps and re position the cameras and go to bed. As soon as I wake up, that scrawny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ breaks my window and smacks me across the face.
I watched the cameras and wait for him to come back.
He comes along and kills my pet pig because he knows I loved him.
One by one, he breaks all the cameras that are facing my camp, effectively blinding me.
I hear footsteps and he walks by my window.
Shot him in the ♥♥♥. He react by screeching and jumping through my window.
Rip. 10/10 would play again.

reviewText: Rake is generally unpolished and has a lot of performance issues on hardware that should be more than capable of handling a game like this. However, if you can ignore the obvious problems, you'll find a pretty interesting game underneath. It can be genuinely tense and atmospheric at times. On the first night of the game, I was anxiously watching the cameras I had set up to get a sight of the Rake. I switched to my fifth camera, and saw him standing right in front of it! He took a couple swipes and destroyed it, so I left the safety of the trailer to go investigate. I had my map up, when I notice out of the corner of my eye a dead pig lying on the ground. I equipped my rifle and started looking around. I hear a quick pitter-patter of footsteps, and turn around. We make eye-contact, and he knocks me over and runs off. The hunt was on.\n\nIf you have a few bucks to spare, I'd suggest giving it a try!

reviewText:
Self multiplying bear traps in multiplayer 10/10

AJ Win!!!

In all seriousness, this was a fun game.  Single player made me almost **** myself and playing it with a friend was both creepy and hilarious.

At the time of this veriew Steam says I've only played two hours of the game, but that's because the multiplayer module launches seperately and doesnt let you use steam in-game (so no steam controller/big picture usability, unfortunately).  I've played probably a combined total of 10 hours with my friend at the time of this review.

One main issue I had is that the Rake is way too hard to shoot.  I haven't tried killing it in Single player, but in Multiplayer it took forever.  My friend and I did actually kill it in multiplayer and had some good laughs doing it, so it wasn't all that bad.  I think the bear traps should actually trap it instead of just damaging it as it runs over the trap.

I also wish the Rake was, I dunno, more dynamic.  The way it attacks feels so repetative that you never really get a chance to shoot it properly, and with that happening over and over again it made me think will this ever end?"

Also
recommended: I wanted to go over and examine my trophy.  But only mere seconds after the screen displayed "AJ WIN!!!"
hoursPlayed: my friend and I were booted out of multiplayer.  How disappointing!  I wanted to take a close up look at the thing I tried so hard to hunt.  Oh well.\n\nDespite its flaws
voteText: overall it's an enjoyable experience
